  1. Introduction

    Thread lifecycle

    
                                    --------<--Waiting <-------------
                                    |                                  |
                                    |                        [call wait(), join()]
                                   \/                                  |
    New -> [call start()] -> Runnable (ready) -> [call run()] -> Running -> [interal return] -> terminated
                                   /\                                 |
                                    |                                 \/
                                    |                        [lock, I/O block]
                                    |                                 |
                                    --------<--Blocked <---------------

    Waiting: The thread is passively waiting for other thread to notify it.

    Blocked: The thread is actively trying to get a lock that is not available.

    Priority

    Each java thread has a priority, from Thread.MIN_PRIORITY (1) to Thread.MAX_PRIORITY (10). The default priority is Thread.NORM_PRIORITY (5).

    Different from C pthread

    1. Java main thread return, the sub-threads continue to run.

    Function

    1. Thread.currentThread(): return a Thread object (handle) that represents the current running thread.
    2. thread.set/getName(String)
    3. thread.set/getPriority(int)

  2. Examples

    1. Create threads

      i. Extends Thread

      Thread class implements the Runnable interface's run, but do nothing. So subclasses should override the Thread's run method to do tasks.

      public class CreateThread extends Thread{

    @Override
    public void run(){
        System.out.println("Sub thread");
    }
    public static void main(String[] args) throws InterruptedException {
        Thread x = new CreateThread();
        System.out.println("Start");
        x.start();
        // x.join();
        System.out.println("End");
    }
}

======== Output ========
Start
End
Sub thread

      ii. Implement Runnable

      Runnable is an interface that defines a run() function.

      public class CreateThread2 implements Runnable{
    @Override
    public void run(){
        System.out.println("SubThread");
    }
    public static void main(String [] args){
        Runnable job = new CreateThread2();
        Thread t = new Thread(job);
        t.start();
        System.out.println("Main end");
    }
}
====== Output ======
Main end
SubThread

      Internally, the two ways are same.

      start() vs. run()

      start() put the thread into a runnable state, and then the thread can invoke the run() method to run it.

      If we directly call the Runnable'run() method in the main thread, it just runs the method directly. The thread class is used to create a seperate thread, and call the run() method.

      run method是留个thread调用的,　不是留给developer调用

      iii. implement runnable by anonymous class

      public class CreateThread3 {
    public static void main(String [] args){
        new Thread(new Runnable() {
            @Override
            public void run() {
                System.out.println("New Thread by anonymous class");
            }
        }).start();
    }
}

      iv. implement runnable with lambda since Java 8

      public class CreateThread4 {
    public static void main(String [] args){
        Thread t = new Thread(()-> System.out.println("Lambda"));
        t.start();
    }
}

    2. Priority

      If two thread has different priorities, the two threads are still running interleaving instead of the low priority thread waits until the high priority thread finished.

      public class Priority extends Thread{
    private String threadName;
    public Priority(String name){
        threadName = name;
    }
    @Override
    public void run(){
        int i = 0;
        while(true) {
            i ++;
            System.out.println("sub thread:" + threadName + " " + i + ";My priority: " + Thread.currentThread().getPriority());
        }
    }
    public static void main(String [] args){
        Thread t1 = new Priority("high");
        t1.setPriority(Thread.MAX_PRIORITY);
        Thread t2 = new Priority("low");
        t2.setPriority(Thread.MIN_PRIORITY);

        t1.start();
        t2.start();
        int i = 0;
        // Thread.currentThread().setPriority(Thread.MIN_PRIORITY);
        while(true){
            //i++;
           // System.out.println("main" + i);
        }
    }
}

  3. Thread Management

    1. Interrupt

      Each thread has two methods interrupt(), isInterrupted(), and an internal interrupted flag.

      interrupt(): e.g. In the main thread to interrupt thread t1, t1.interrupt(). It will set the interrupt flag.
      interrupted flag: Interrupt flag is set by the interrupt() function, it will be cleared if the thread can throw the InterruptException. e.g. sleep()
      isInterrupted(): return the interrupted flag.

      * After interrupting a thread, the thread is continuing running.

      public class ThreadManage {
    public static void main(String [] args) throws InterruptedException{
        Thread t1 = new Thread(new Runnable() {
            @Override
            public void run() {
                while (!Thread.currentThread().isInterrupted()){
                    System.out.println(Thread.currentThread().getName() + Thread.currentThread().isInterrupted());
                }
            }
        });

        Thread t2 = new Thread(()->{
            while(true){
                System.out.println(Thread.currentThread().getName() + Thread.currentThread().isInterrupted() );
                try{
                    Thread.sleep(1000);
                }catch (InterruptedException e){
                    System.out.println("return : is interrupted " +  Thread.currentThread().isInterrupted());
                    return;
                }
            }
        });
        t1.setName("While thread ");
        t2.setName("Sleep thread ");
        t1.start();
        t2.start();
        Thread.sleep(20);
        t1.interrupt();
        System.out.println(t1.isInterrupted());
        Thread.sleep(2000);
        t2.interrupt();
        // Thread.sleep(20);
        System.out.println(t2.isInterrupted()); 
        // The above statement print true, because the interrupt function and isInterrupted function are executed together.
        // The sleep function does not throw the exception and reset the flag yet.
        // In the handler, the isInterrupted is false.
    }
}

    2. Synchronized block

      Synchronized block guarantee the executing sequence of multithread

      The synchronized block can be in 4 scenario.

      i. instance method
      ii. static class method
      iii. code blocks inside instance method
      iv. code blocks inside static class method

      synchronized instance method

      The sychronized unit is object. All synchronized methods in an instance use one "lock".

      Synchronized instance methods in an instance are synchronized on the instance itself.

      public class ThreadManage2 {
    public static void main(String [] args) throws InterruptedException {
        final Sync s = new Sync(0);
        // final Sync s2 = new Sync(0);
        Thread t1 = new Thread(()->s.dec());
        Thread t2 = new Thread(()->s.inc());
// dec() and inc() use the same lock even though they are not the same object.

        t1.start();
        Thread.sleep(100);
        t2.start();
        System.out.println("start");
        t2.join(); // blocked here
        System.out.println("t2 end");
        t1.join();
        System.out.println("end");
    }
}
class Sync{
    private int i;
    public Sync(int i){
        this.i = i;
    }
    public synchronized void dec(){
        while (i <= 0);
        i--;
    }
    public synchronized void inc(){
        i++;
    }
}

      synchronized class static method

      Different from instance methods, each static method has its own lock.

      public class ThreadManage2 {
    public static void main(String [] args) throws InterruptedException {
        final Sync s = new Sync(0);
        // final Sync s2 = new Sync(0);
        Thread t1 = new Thread(()->s.dec());
        Thread t2 = new Thread(()->s.inc());
        Thread t3 = new Thread(()->Sync.waiting());
        Thread t4 = new Thread(()->Sync.waiting());
        t3.setName("t3 ");
        t4.setName("t4 ");


        t3.start();
        Thread.sleep(100);
        t4.start();
        t2.start();
        Thread.sleep(100);
        t1.start();
        System.out.println("start");
        t3.join();
        t4.join();

        t2.join();
        System.out.println("t2 end");
        t1.join();
        System.out.println("end");
    }
}
class Sync{
    private int i;
    public Sync(int i){
        this.i = i;
    }
    public synchronized void dec(){
        while (i <= 0);
        i--;
        System.out.println("dec end");
    }
    public synchronized void inc(){
        i++;
    }
    public synchronized static void waiting(){
        System.out.println(Thread.currentThread().getName() + " run");
        while(true);
    }
}
// waiting has one lock, dec and inc share one lock

      Synchronized code block in instance methods

      Sometimes, it is not necessary to synchronize the entire method.

      Synchronized block also need to select the target sync object. Usually, it is just the instance itself, this.

      public class ThreadManage4 {
    // private String name;
    public void func1(){
        synchronized (this){
            while(true);
        }
    }
    public void func2(){
        synchronized (this){
            System.out.println("func2");
        }
    }
    public void func3(){
        synchronized (this.toString()){
            System.out.println("func3");
        }
    }
    public static void main(String []args) throws InterruptedException{
        ThreadManage4 m4 = new ThreadManage4();
        Thread t1 = new Thread(()->m4.func1());
        Thread t2 = new Thread(()->m4.func2());
        Thread t3 = new Thread(()->m4.func3());
        t1.start();
        Thread.sleep(1000);
        t2.start();
        t3.start();
        t2.join();
        t3.join();
        // t1 blocks t2, but t3 synchronizes on a different object, so t3 can run.
    }
}

      Synchronized code block in class static methods

      It is same as the code block in instance methods but cannot use "this".

    3. Wait notfiy

      Wait/notify to achieve a bounded buffer. Different from CV in POSIX:
      1. POSIX: a lock can bind to serveral cv. Java: a object is a cv and a lock. synchronized(this) is to lock 

      import java.util.LinkedList;

public class BB {
    private LinkedList<String> container;
    private int size;
    private int len;

    public BB(int size){
        this.size = 0;
        len = 0;
        container = new LinkedList<>();
    }

    public synchronized boolean push(String value){
        while(len > this.size){
            try {
                this.wait();
            }catch (InterruptedException e){
                System.out.println("Push failed, it is interrupted.");
                return false;
            }
        }
        len++;
        System.out.println("push");
        container.add(value);
        this.notifyAll();
        return true;
    }
    public synchronized String pop(){
        while(len <= 0){
            try{
                this.wait();
            }catch (InterruptedException e){
                System.out.println("Pop failed, it is interrupted.");
                return null;
            }
        }
        len--;
        System.out.println("pop");
        String value = container.remove(len);
        this.notifyAll();
        return value;
    }

    public static void main(String [] args){
        BB bb = new BB(1);
        Thread t1 = new Thread(()->{
            while(true){

                bb.pop();
            }
        });
        Thread t2 = new Thread(()->{
            while(true) {

                bb.push("first");
            }
        });
        t1.start();
        t2.start();
        System.out.println("end");
    }
}

  4. References

    1. Synchronized block
